question: Fensterwald. Carswell Fensterwald. It sounds familiar but... They sure come out of the woodwork when you get famous, Clair. Put him through.
answer: Long time no see, huh? You have a big book out. Things are clicking, huh?

question: That's the way I planned it.
answer: Listen, Leo, I'm closing my practice. Most of my patients are on the West Side but I have one case I'd like to refer you.

question: Carswell, thanks but --
answer: I know, you're incredibly busy.

question: Swamped. I've raised my rate. I might even cut my sessions to forty minutes...
answer: Leo, I know you don't like flattery but if anybody I know is going to win a Nobel Prize, it's you. You gotta be thinking about your next book so I know you'll find this case particularly interesting.

question: What sort of case is it, Carswell?
answer: Actually, Leo, I don't know.

question: Carswell, if this is a dysfunctional --
answer: No no, nothing like that. He keeps his appointments. Pays on time. See him once. If he's not the most complex and -- persistent -- case you've ever seen, drop him. His name's Bob Wiley. He needs someone brilliant.

question: Okay. I'll work him in for an interview. Say, Carswell, how come you're quitting the business?
answer: We're a dying breed, Leo. Good luck. I feel good. I feel great. I feel wonderful!

question: I feel good. I feel great. I feel wonderful! I feel good, I feel great! I feel -- Morning, Gil. Mrs. Lions, I'm Bob Wiley. I represent the Manhattan Dental Hygiene Association. I can offer you a forty percent discount on our toothpicks plus a very attractive selection of toothpick holders if...
answer: Mr. Wiley --

question: Bob.
answer: Bob, this is an elementary school.

question: Elementary school? I thought you were Overton Cafeteria? I don't know. A young tooth is a terrible thing to waste. I should know. When I was that age nobody gave a hoot about my teeth and now they're terrible! Have you checked out flavored floss?
answer: Flavored floss?

question: All you have to do is dream pink gums, Patsy, and we can make them happen. Give me your address and I'll send you our flossing catalogue. I feel good, I feel great, I feel wonderful. I'm going to see Dr. Leo Marvin. Elevator. Thanks. I feel good, I feel great, I feel wonderful. Hi... I'm... Bob... Dr. Marvin. Bob Wiley. Thank you for working me in. Your family? Wait, let me guess. I'm good at this. Harriet, Kenny, Gretchen, Rita. Wait wait, I know I'm close. Susan, Steven, Andrea, Rita. Wait --
answer: My wife, Fay. My son, Sigmund. My daughter, Anna. My sister, Lily.

question: Lily... I was close! What a wonderful family!
answer: Thank you.

question: Do I call you Dr. Marvin or Leo?
answer: Whichever you prefer. Have a seat.

question: Call me Bob. Thank you. I guess I'm on, huh? Well, the simplest way to put it is, I have problems. I worry er, about diseases. I have trouble with toothbrushes. And I, er, I have problems moving.
answer: Talk about moving.

question: As long as I'm in my apartment, I'm okay. I have a phone job -- selling dental supplies -- and that's fine. But when I have to go out, I get..., weird.
answer: Talk about weird.

question: I get dizzy spells. Nausea. Cold sweats. Hot sweats. Fever blisters. Difficulty swallowing. Difficulty breathing. Blurred vision. Involuntary trembling. Dead hands. Weak ankles. Twitching. Fainting spells. Numb lips. Do you think that's normal?
answer: That depends. You do go out, you know.

question: I do?
answer: You came here.

question: You're right!
answer: What are you afraid of?

question: Well. What if I break my neck and become paraplegic? What if my heart stops beating, or I can't find a bathroom and my bladder explodes? You ever heard of Tourette's Syndrome. You know, where you involuntarily shout profanity?
answer: That's exceptionally rare.

question: I have a neighbor who got it. Yells "oh shit!" in church. "Douche bag!" at customers at his job. Pretty funny, actually, unless you're the one with the disease. Then it's sad. OH SHIT EATING SON OF A BITCH! Just kidding. TWAT LOVING DOUCHE BAG!
answer: Why are you doing this?

question: Sometimes, if I fake it, I know I don't have it. Like, when I think my heart is gonna stop. I fake it so I know it's not happening. If I can't make it happen, I know it's not happening. I know it's all in my mind. Get away from me with that knife! See?
answer: Are you married?

question: Divorced, actually.
answer: Want to talk about it?

question: The world is divided into two types of people
answer: Um.

question: Dr. Marvin, do you think you can help me?
answer: There's a saying, Bob, that the best psychiatrist in the world is right inside of you. I can help you, provided you're willing to help yourself.

question: Are you kidding, I'll do anything!
answer: There's a ground breaking book that just came out, Bob. Not everything in it applies to you but when you see the title, I think you'll see that it can help.

question: Baby Steps.
answer: It means setting small, reasonable goals for yourself. One day at a time, one tiny step at a time -- do- able, accomplishable goals.

question: Baby steps.
answer: When you leave this office, don't think about everything you have to do to get out of the building, just deal with getting out of the room. When you reach the hall, just deal with the hall. And so forth. Baby steps.

question: Baby step... through the office. Baby step... out the door. It works!
answer: Of course.

question: All I have to do is take one small step at a time and I can do anything!
answer: Exactly. But don't expect everything all at once. Even a baby occasionally falls and hits his head.

question: Baby step around the office. Baby step around the office! Fay, Sigmund, Anna, Lily
answer: This will give you plenty to digest while I'm on vacation.

question: Vacation?
answer: Certainly my secretary told you. As of this afternoon, I'm on vacation with my family until Labor Day.

question: That's a whole month! What if I need you? What if I need to talk?
answer: Dr. Harmon, my associate will be happy to talk. We have years ahead of us, Bob. A month will seem like a baby second.

question: Can I call you in the Hamptons if I need you?
answer: Dr. Harmon is quite skilled.

question: I hear Maine is great this time of year.
answer: I'll be with you the whole month. Try your baby steps.

question: Let's see... Baby step through the office. Baby step out the door.
answer: That's perfect. Keep going...

question: Baby steps to the hall. Baby... It's the Catskills, isn't it?
answer: Bob...

question: Sorry. Baby steps. Baby steps... You flying or driving?
answer: Bob. I'll be back.

question: Baby steps, he'll be back. Baby steps, he'll be back...
answer: July 31, Bob Wiley, introductory interview. Multi-phobic personality characterized by an extreme need for family connections. Bill $150 for the session and $29.95 for the book. Bob...

question: Baby step to the elevator. Baby step to the elevator. Baby step to the elevator. Baby step to the elevator.
answer: Hurry hurry hurry. Hurry hurry hurry. Hurry hurry hurry. Honey there isn't time. You're only encouraging them, Fay. Hurry hurry hurry. Hurry hurry hurry...

question: Okay, how does this sound? Tomorrow
answer: Ooo, sounds great.

question: Wednesday we'll re-arrange the furniture and spruce up the lawn.
answer: More, I gotta have more.

question: Can I help you, bub?
answer: Bob.

question: Would you like a hot dog, Bob?
answer: I sure would...

question: Mustard?
answer: I sure would.

question: Sauerkraut.
answer: I'd love it. But I can't. I really want to but I can't. It's bird intestine and beef brain.

question: Hit the road, bub.
answer: Bob. Hi, mom.

question: Bob. Hi, mom.
answer: Bob, you didn't walk up again?

question: I found this great psychiatrist who abandoned me.
answer: Did you come here for money?

question: Mom, that's a terrible thing to ask.
answer: How do you like my latest?

question: It's lovely mom.
answer: Bobby, please!

question: Mom, I'm sorry! All I wanted to do was talk. I'll go.
answer: Oh my poor baby. How did you get so screwed up?

question: Oh, mom.
answer: You're the only thing I care about. Always will be.

question: Oh mom.
answer: I'm here for you, Bob. Anytime.

question: I love you, mom.
answer: Go home, sweetie. I need to work.

question: Baby step across the street. Baby step across the street... I feel good, I feel great, I feel wonderful.
answer: Hi.

question: Whoa!... You're really getting big. What a bruiser. Hi little Bobby!
answer: Bob, he's not little Bobby. Feel the heartbeat?

question: Oh, Becky, let's get married again.
answer: Bob. You know I'm married to some one else now.

question: But I want a baby. A family! I want to burp him and change him and... love him! Why couldn't it have been with me?
answer: Bob, honey, we've been over this. You as a father? Think about it. You know I actually have considered naming him "Bob".

question: Really?!
answer: Yeah. But it's still going to be "Neil".

question: Right.
answer: I'm sorry Mr. Wiley --

question: Bob.
answer: -- Bob, but Dr. Marvin is out of town and Dr. Harmon is taking his calls.

question: I don't want Harmon, I need Marvin! Look, there seems to be some confusion. You see, Dr. Marvin, uh, Leo, wanted me to call him but I lost his number.
answer: Bob. I can't give out that number.

question: But you could call him and ask him to call me.
answer: It's awfully late. Stay on the line, Bob. What's your number in case we get disconnected?

question: It's awfully late. Stay on the line, Bob. What's your number in case we get disconnected?
answer: Yes?

question: Dr. Marvin, this is Bessie at your exchange. I'm sorry to disturb you but I have a Bob Wiley on the line who says you'll want to talk to him.
answer: You know better than this, Bessie. Dr. Harmon is covering for me.

question: I told him that, Doctor, but he insists on talking to you. He says it's an emergency.
answer: Put him through.

question: Go ahead, Bob.
answer: Bob, I thought I made it clear to you that I'm on vacation.

question: Bob, I thought I made it clear to you that I'm on vacation.
answer: I know, but I'm a mess. Worse than usual.

question: Bob, if this is an emergency, go to the emergency room. If not, call Dr. Harmon and I'm sure he can help you.
answer: I'd feel better if I just knew where you were. It's Martha's Vineyard right?

question: Bob.
answer: Couldn't we just talk?

question: In my office, after Labor Day.
answer: Fire Island?

question: Good night, Bob.
answer: Hi, this is Bob. Leo and I got cut off.

question: Hi, this is Bob. Leo and I got cut off.
answer: I'm sorry, Bob, but Dr. Marvin just called and instructed me not to put you through.

question: What?
answer: Mid-Manhattan exchange. I'm not allowed to give out that number. Don't you have it? Stay on the line, Miss Marvin.

question: Thanks. You were fantastic.
answer: Lily? What's wrong?

question: Dr. Marvin, please don't be angry. It's Bob. I know I shouldn't call this way but --
answer: Bob, listen to me. The doctor-patient relationship is based on trust. When you call me against my wishes or pretend to be my sister, I can't trust you any more.

question: I know but--
answer: Call Dr. Harmon, or go to the emergency room, but don't call me here again.

question: Oh that wasn't smart! Oh that wasn't smart...
answer: That was that sicko who kept calling Dr. Marvin. What about him? Oh my god. What happened?

question: Suicide. We think. Forty stories. Free fall. Splat. Now our records show that Bob made several calls to this number just before he died. Did either of you know Bob personally?
answer: Bob called here trying to reach his psychiatrist.

question: That's interesting. What happened? Uh HUH.
answer: Wait a minute. Dr. Marvin couldn't have had anything to do with Bob's death.

question: Oh? Why not?
answer: Dr. Marvin's on vacation.

question: Ah. Michigan?
answer: New Hampshire.

question: Right.
answer: We're not supposed to give out the number but I can call him and...

question: That's okay. I'm sure we can find him if we need him.
answer: God, I feel terrible. What if I was the last person he talked to before he died?

question: Dr. Marvin! It's me, Bob!
answer: Get in the car.

question: Hi! This is Gil. It must be fate that I found you so quickly! Is this a bad time?
answer: What are you doing here? I thought you were..., dead.

question: Oh no, they told you? I fibbed a little but... Don't be mad. Oh... The fam.
answer: I think you know, Bob, that your behavior is entirely inappropriate. We talked about trust. We talked about my needs. I want you to get on a bus and go back to New York.

question: You're angry.
answer: I don't get angry.

question: You're upset.
answer: I don't get upset.

question: Then can't we just talk?
answer: I don't see patients on vacation, Bob. Ever. How many ways can I make that clear?

question: But you can't just send me away! I've read your book, I've been doing what you told me, but I've completely relapsed! A little time would mean so much. Please.
answer: Bob, I'm driving away now and I don't want you to bother me again. You came for my advice, correct?

question: Absolutely.
answer: Then take my advice and go back to New York.

question: But I can't go anywhere! I'm all locked up!
answer: You got yourself here.

question: Barely!
answer: Getting back will therapeutic.

question: Please just talk to me. Just a little talk.
answer: You're testing my patience, Bob.

question: A teeny tiny talk. An itty bitty talk... Pretty please... Pretty please with sugar...
answer: Get up. Come on, get up.

question: Say you will. Please, say you will.
answer: Bob, it's two o'clock. Go to the bus station, buy a ticket home, then wait in that restaurant.

question: You'll meet me?!
answer: I'll call you. In two hours.

question: Oh my god, you're the greatest!
answer: But you must buy your ticket and give your word that you'll go home. This is all about trust again, Bob. We must have trust.

question: I trust. I absolutely trust. I'll go buy my ticket. Right now!
answer: I'll call you at four.

question: You couldn't possibly make it three thirty, could you?
answer: Bob...

question: Baby step to four o'clock. Baby step to four o'clock. I feel good, I feel great, I feel four o'clock! Huh? Oh. Thanks. Thank you. Can you make it four o'clock? Dr. Marvin's supposed to call me then but I'm going crazy.
answer: Not Dr. Leo Marvin?

question: Do you know him?
answer: He bought our dream house. We worked a lifetime, saved up for a down payment, then he swooped down with his fancy schmancy lawyers and grabbed it out from under us. Like the plague.

question: Take off your robe. Everything you wear is black. I wish you'd get off this death fixation.
answer: How do you know it's a death fixation? Maybe I'm in mourning for my lost childhood.

question: What do you mean by that?
answer: What do you mean by asking?

question: Come on, get on the board and let's see your approach.
answer: My approach is to be suave and debonair and sophisticated.

question: Come on, Siggy. 1, 2, 3 spring. Like we learned last time. 1, 2, 3, spring.
answer: 1, 2, 3 spring. 1, 2, 3 summer. 1, 2, 3 fall. Time to go dad.

question: Cut it out, Siggy. Left foot...
answer: This is no fun.

question: Why didn't you dive?
answer: With all the horror that's going on in the world, what difference does it make?

question: It's not like I'm making him jump out of an airplane. When I was growing up, I thought diving was fun.
answer: I thought you were born grown up.

question: You're masking hostility, Anna Marvin. Turn that down.
answer: It's full of Freudian symbols, dad. It's educational.

question: You too. Great place. No wonder the Guttmans wanted it. I really feel bad about barging in like this.
answer: Forget it. I understand.

question: You do?
answer: Of course I do. Your problems don't go away just because I go on vacation. They've been with you a long time after all.

question: Ever since I can remember.
answer: On the other hand, you're making strides. You got here.

question: I baby stepped. I owe it to you.
answer: Bob, take a look around you. What does everything you see have in common?

question: Er... I don't know... It's all owned by you, that's obvious. Humm... Everything's from a garage sale!
answer: Vacation, Bob. Everything you see is part of a vacation. Every year, for one month, I bring my family to this house on vacation. Nice, isn't it?

question: It's wonderful. The lake. The trees. The little town.
answer: Do you know what the point of a vacation is? Do you understand the meaning of the word?

question: Sure.
answer: You forget about your troubles. You give up your worries. You drink from the wellspring of relaxation that enriches your soul. Now I can't, at this time, give you the kind of therapeutic attention that you need to solve all your problems. Know why?

question: Er, because you're on vacation?
answer: Excellent. But what I can do -- and only I can do this because you trust me don't you Bob?

question: Why else would I be here?
answer: Exactly. What I can do is this. Get on your bus and go back to New York. Every time a problem comes up, follow this prescription.

question: I don't need pills. I have plenty of pills.
answer: It's not pills. Read it.

question: It says
answer: I'm giving you permission to take a vacation, Bob. Not a vacation from your work. Not a vacation from your daily life. But a vacation from...

question: My problems.
answer: Every time you feel a problem coming on, take that out and follow it to the letter. Doctors orders.

question: Doctors orders.
answer: I'm glad you came. I'll see you in my office next month.

question: That's it?
answer: You came here for relief, Bob. Read your prescription.

question: This is... INCREDIBLE! This is ASTOUNDING!! For the first time since Menningers I feel free! I knew coming up here was the right thing to do!
answer: It feels right because you're here and because you're leaving.

question: You've given me a great gift, doctor. The gift of life. You're a great man.
answer: If you have any questions, call Dr. Harmon.

question: Have a great vacation!
answer: You too.

question: A vacation from my problems. You bet I will! My fish.
answer: Oh. Right.

question: You must be Sigmund.
answer: Siggy, this is Bob. He's just leaving.

question: Hi.
answer: Hi. This is Gil. My fish.

question: Cool. Did you get him out of the lake?
answer: No. He's a city fish.

question: Cool.
answer: Your father is the most incredible psychiatrist in the world! You better appreciate him. Have a great vacation, fam.

question: It's too close to the wall.
answer: Who cares?

question: I care, and you should too. Our house is going on national television tomorrow. You want your friends to think you live in a dump?
answer: My friends would respect me for it.

question: You know, there's nothing wrong with neatness. People joke but it's actually a sign of a creative intelligence. Right, Fay?
answer: In isolated cases, sure.

question: What is that supposed to mean?
answer: The room looks wonderful, dear.

question: I'll get it. It's probably the van with my art.
answer: Good morning! I'll bet you're surprised to see me! When I walked out of here last night I said to myself, "Dr. Marvin's absolutely right. Take a vacation from your problems. Blow em off. Just say 'no'." So I did!

question: But... You're back.
answer: No I'm not.

question: You're not?!
answer: Of course not. I'm taking a vacation. This isn't an appointment, I'm dropping by. I told the Guttmans what you said and they found me a cottage nearby.

question: No...
answer: Yeah, the town is packed but I guess if you know the right people... Anyway, I know we can't work but let's get the friendship thing going. I'm a little anxious about being here by myself but I don't want to barge in. I'll call. Give my best to the fam and see ya around, okay?

question: Where are you off to?
answer: Sailing.

question: With Teddy Fein?
answer: No. George Stark. The boy from the plane.

question: It's a quarter mile to the marina. Why do you need the car?
answer: I'm picking everybody up.

question: Stay out of the sun! Remember what's happening to the ozone layer.
answer: Bob! Hi! Where you going?

question: Bob! Hi! Where you going?
answer: Just to... town. Buy some..., Kleenex.

question: Want a ride?
answer: I don't think your dad would like you picking me up.

question: He wouldn't like a lot of things. Hop in.
answer: He seemed pretty upset this morning.

question: He's nervous about the interview.
answer: Interview?

question: Maria Shriver's coming tomorrow to talk about his book.
answer: Wow... so that's the problem! And I thought he was upset about me!

question: Well he's always uptight, even when it doesn't show.
answer: He is?

question: Sure. Imagine growing up with a dad who sees every stage of growing up as a Freudian passage. Did you ever have crayons?
answer: Sure.

question: Fat or skinny?
answer: Er, skinny, I think.

question: Uh oh.
answer: What do you mean?

question: Dad saw crayons as phallic symbols. When I asked for skinny crayons, it was a personal assault on his manhood.
answer: What'd he do, buy a Porsche?

question: I wish! He just kept psychoanalyzing everything. My dolls were alter egos. Boys who wanted to kiss me were Oedipally fixated adolescents looking to displace their mothers on their aboriginal family totems.
answer: Sounds like my friends to a tee. You seem to be doing okay now.

question: Hardly. I analyze everything to death. Every time a guy smiles at me, I ask myself is he really smiling or is he just orally fixated? When I smile back, I wonder, am I really attracted or just smiling out of some residual Cro-Magnon instinct? If I ever actually have sex, I'm not sure I'll know the difference between an orgasm and an anxiety attack!
answer: I have the same problem.

question: The kinds of urges other girls act on impulsively, I analyze until either the urge goes away or --
answer: Or what?

question: The boy goes away.
answer: Well. It sounds like your dad never learned to leave his work at the office.

question: Lot of good it does me!
answer: You'll make some man very happy someday.

question: What are you doing today?
answer: Buying Kleenex.

question: Wanna come sailing?
answer: Well, I... I, er...

question: That's okay. You don't have to.
answer: Actually, it's not that I don't want to go. It's just that I've never been on a boat and I'm not sure I can handle it.

question: There's nothing to it. George Stark's doing the sailing.
answer: Just thinking about gives me hives. You're right, this is great! I never actually thought I could do this. I never thought this could be me!

question: I want to see Anna alone. I thought I told you to stay away from Bob Wiley.
answer: No. You just said I couldn't let him in the house. Daddy, where are we going?

question: Home.
answer: What about the car? I left it at the pier.

question: Leave it. It's been a while since I've had a walk with my daughter.
answer: Daddy, not here!

question: Leo, Siggy is really upset. Leo...
answer: Fay, I'm a failure.

question: What?
answer: Our daughter, our only daughter, has fallen for a brilliant manipulator twice her age.

question: Leo, for god's sake talk sense.
answer: Anna and Bob!

question: Face a fear and it goes away.
answer: Okay. I'm facing it, now what do I do?

question: Hit it. Fast. While it isn't looking.
answer: My mind says "yes yes" but my body says "no no". It's hopeless.

question: For God's sake, I'm even a failure in my own book! Can you believe it? In Chapter 2, I wrote that a healthy adolescent girl can never have a sublimated father complex and my daughter has one.
answer: It's a brief flirtation, honey. Anna's perfectly healthy.

question: Then you're saying the book's wrong?
answer: Better that than Anna.

question: Fay, my god!
answer: Leo, what? Leo, what is it?

question: Don't think about boiling oil!
answer: I'm not.

question: Or searing acid!
answer: I'm not!

question: Our Father, we commit this soul to the sea.
answer: Yeah!

question: I'm doomed!
answer: No you're not.

question: I'll be a laughing stock!
answer: No you won't. You've blow this way out of proportion, Leo, and you have to get control. Now try your breathing.

question: Okay. I'm being ridiculous. You're right. It's a brilliant book... Our daughter's fine... I'm great.
answer: That's right.

question: Fay, do you remember a Carswell Fensterwald?
answer: My God, Leo, look at this.

question: The name is so familiar but --
answer: Leo, Siggy's diving!

question: What? I'll put a stop to this!
answer: Leo!

question: Enough. Let go of him! That's enough!
answer: Leo!

question: But he did. I'm not saying I was right, but Bob can do a lot of things no one thought he could do. Look, I said I was wrong now I'd like to forget it. I'd like you all to accept my apology.
answer: What about Bob?

question: What about Bob?!
answer: Don't you think you should apologize to him?

question: I will not apologize to Bob.
answer: Why not?

question: Mmmm. Mmmmm. This sure is good. Mmmm. Mmmmm. Mmmmm.
answer: Would you please stop that?

question: Oh. Sorry, Leo. Would you pass the salt?
answer: And don't call me Leo.

question: I'm sorry. You said in your office that I could call you Leo.
answer: That was in my office. In my home you will call me Dr. Marvin.

question: Did I say that? I'll drive him.
answer: The car's still in town, daddy.

question: What?
answer: You said to leave it, remember? We walked home.

question: He can borrow my slicker.
answer: Leo.

question: Shsh.
answer: Leo...

question: Quiet. It's letting up.
answer: Leo, we can't make the poor fellow sit here all night. Let's let him stay over.

question: Stay over? Honey, Maria Shriver's coming in the morning. Maria Shriver! You want some guy sleeping on our couch when Maria Shriver gets here?
answer: There's an extra bed in Siggy's room. Bob, would you like to spend the night?

question: Have you seen my new toothbrush?
answer: It should be in the bathroom.

question: Well it should be but it's not!
answer: Just because you're nervous about tomorrow, Leo Marvin, doesn't give you the right to get snippy. If you can't handle the pressure, postpone the interview.

question: Fay, it's not the interview -- I mean I am nervous about it -- but that's not what's bugging me. It's... him.
answer: Him who? Bob?

question: No, Siggy. Yes, Bob! Who else?
answer: Leo, quiet. He'll hear you.

question: Why shouldn't he hear me? Don't you get it, he's a sick person. A multiphobic mess! He faked suicide...
answer: Isn't that a cry for help?

question: ...Followed me up here from New York, wormed his way into my house. For all I know, he's a mass murderer!
answer: Oh come on, Leo, he's a sweet guy. Perfectly harmless.

question: Bob?
answer: Yeah.

question: How come you go to dad? Are you really sick or just maladjusted?
answer: Sick. You ever had a bee buzz your face that wouldn't go away?

question: Sure. Once or twice.
answer: When I was twelve, I had one buzz me for three weeks. Whoa. You got some heavy stuff here. Denial of Death, Fear and Trembling, Sickness Unto Death.

question: Those are dad's.
answer: He lets you read this stuff?

question: He hid them but I found them. Bob?
answer: Yeah?

question: Are you afraid of death?
answer: Sure. Are you kidding?

question: What do you do about it? I mean, how do you cope?
answer: Well... The way I figure it, if it weren't called "death", it wouldn't be so bad. I mean what if it were called "dink"?

question: Dink?
answer: Then it would be fine. We'd say "Grandma dinked." "The garbage man dinked."

question: My turtle just dinked.
answer: Exactly. Then we wouldn't worry anymore.

question: Hey, you're right!
answer: 'Course we'd still have to worry about Barrett's Esophagus and Black Water Fever and Tourette's Syndrome.

question: What's Tourette's syndrome? FART BRAIN!
answer: BOOGER HEAD!

question: We got carried away. We won't do it again.
answer: I want you out by six thirty. Understand. Maria Shriver comes at seven, I want you out by six thirty.

question: Sure. Would you like something for sleep?
answer: What?

question: I've got Valium if you need it.
answer: I don't need Valium.

question: Halcyon? Seconal?
answer: I need peace and quiet!

question: It's my fault, Mrs. M., we should have been quieter.
answer: We just have to get him through Maria Shriver. Sleep tight. Don't let the bed bugs bite.

question: Bed bugs!
answer: It's just an expression.

question: Oh right. 'Night. Mrs. M! Would you mind leaving it cracked?
answer: Six o'clock, rise and shine! Rise and shine. Six o'clock. Rise and shine, rise and shine. Bob... Bob! BOB!

question: AHHHH! Baby stepping down the stairs. Baby stepping down the stairs! Hello! Is this a beautiful day or what?
answer: Leave.

question: I had the most incredible dream last night, I --
answer: Go.

question: Is this something you want me to work out on my own?
answer: Now!

question: Hello.
answer: I hope we're not too early. May we come in?

question: Sure. I thought by the fireplace...
answer: This is even nicer than the pictures.

question: Thank you.
answer: Is this your family?

question: Dr. Marvin, it takes a remarkable amount of confidence in your methods to bring on a patient with you. What in particular about Bob's prior condition would you like to share with us?
answer: Nothing.

question: Nothing? Nothing in particular you think we should know?
answer: No.

question: Hum... Well... Let me try you, Bob.
answer: Okay.

question: Have you been a patient of Dr. Marvin's for a long time?
answer: Long time? I wouldn't call it a long time. What? Three or four days?

question: Days?!
answer: Why you sly dogs, he was right! I want to say that if more wisdom, or more empathy, or more pure intelligence exists than exits in this man, I want to know about it. Do you know that he actually had me sleep here last night? In his jamies, using his toothbrush!

question: Get out.
answer: Is it something, I said?

question: GET OUT!!
answer: Is this aversion therapy?

question: GO AWAY NOW!
answer: Okay.

question: I never had a father, really. Dad left one morning and never came back. My earliest memory is mom with a suitcase. Do you think that's significant? I'd like to do some free association about my infancy Will do! Wherever we're going, Fay wants us home by seven.
answer: No problem.

question: It's a combustible relationship, isn't it? Is it just you and me or is it you and everybody? So what's the big surprise?
answer: Intensive psychotherapy.

question: Really?!
answer: Isn't that what you came here for?

question: Yeah! But what brought this on now?
answer: You're ready.

question: Wow. This is exciting.
answer: Leo Marvin to see Dr. Tomsky.

question: Where are we?
answer: Therapy land, Bob. A twentieth century theme park of the mind. The lines look short today. Bob Wiley, this is your new pal, Dr. Tomsky.

question: New pal? What's wrong with my old pal? Hey! Don't touch me! I have seizures! Dr. M! Dr. M!!
answer: I really appreciate your helping me out on this, Kenneth.

question: Yeah, dad, where's Bob?
answer: Can't a man enjoy himself on vacation?

question: Dad -- ?
answer: Bob sends his regrets but he had to take a trip.

question: What kind of trip? I thought you were working with him.
answer: I was.

question: Then why'd he go on a trip?
answer: Why does a man climb a mountain, Anna? Because it's there.

question: Kenneth, you have been duped by a textbook narcissist. A brilliant neuropath!
answer: Brilliant enough to dupe my entire staff? I doubt that. I'm giving you back his admitting forms, Leo, to save you any embarrassment.

question: Embarrassment?!
answer: It's perfectly natural for a patient to bond with his analyst. It's a normal part of therapy. If you want to be rid of him, simply take him back where you got him and go home.

question: That's easy for you to say! He's human crazy glue! If it were that simple do you think I'd be here?
answer: You should have never let him sleep in your pajamas, Leo. His problems don't go away just because you want them too.

question: Whose side are you on?!
answer: Relax, Leo.

question: I'm relaxed!
answer: Take a vacation.

question: I'm on vacation!!
answer: Are you sure? Maybe you should check in here for a few days and get a handle on things?

question: Intensive psychotherapy? -- boy, you weren't kidding, were you? I mean even Dr. T. didn't think I needed that. Look I have an idea -- how are your afternoons? I mean since we're here together with nothing else to do, what say we work from two to four, something like that?
answer: Get out! Get out of my car, get out of my life, don't ever come back!

question: Are you saying you'd prefer mornings? What is this, isolation therapy? You're the doctor.
answer: No! You won't catch me!! NO!

question: Need any help?
answer: No!

question: Remember
answer: Shit! First he ruins my life, now he ruins my tire! God! Damn! Son of a bitching! Bob! Shit piss crap! Son of a bitching douche bag asshole! What about Bob?! Think about Bob! What about Bob? What about Bob? WHAT ABOUT BOB!! I'm home!

question: You feeling better?
answer: I'm fine. It's your dad I'm worried about. How is he?

question: Upstairs. Resting. I can't understand why he'd attack you like that.
answer: I can't either. But one thing I've learned about psychiatrists

question: Bob, we've talked about this.
answer: No, you've talked about it and I've listened. In my opinion, George Stark's smile is not Oedipal regression and it's not confused libido. It's one good looking guy drooling over you, Anna Marvin.

question: Bob...
answer: Go ask if you can put your tongue in his mouth. I hear it works every time. A pleasure. I'm neurotic too. Only in a good way. Sit down. It must be nice having an analyst in the family. You're kidding?!

question: That should give you some interesting ideas for your next book. You might even wake up feeling happy.
answer: I doubt it. Phil, do you remember a classmate named Fensterwald?

question: Carswell Fensterwald? Sure. Who could forget?
answer: I've forgotten and I don't know why. Did anything unusual happen with him?

question: You're joking.
answer: Do I act like a man who's joking?!

question: Relax, Leo. I just can't believe you'd block something like that out. Carswell was at Harvard with us. You turned him in for cheating.
answer: What...?

question: Don't you remember? You brought action against him for stealing your psychoanalysis notes and they booted him. The only place that would take him after that was University of Guadalajara.
answer: Thanks, Phil. Enjoy the party. Baby steps, make a plan.

question: Thanks, Phil. Enjoy the party. Baby steps, make a plan.
answer: Can I help you, doctor?

question: I want to buy a gun.
answer: Okay. I've got Winchesters. Colts. What do you plan on hunting?

question: Er. An animal. This tall. Hundred and seventy pounds. Bermuda shorts.
answer: Take a look at this baby. It'll shoot through anything but it also leaves a clean wound. Your wife was in with that Bob fellow. Sure is a nice guy.

question: What do you have that leaves a messy wound?
answer: I'll need you driver's license, social security number, and you can pick them up on Friday... the 18th.

question: The eighteenth?
answer: There's a two week waiting period in this state.

question: I can't wait two weeks! I need these now!
answer: Dr. Marvin, it's the law.

question: Bye, fam. I guess this is good-bye, fam.
answer: Get up and don't make a sound!

question: Dr. M.! Everybody's looking for you.
answer: I said shut up!

question: Okay. You're the doc. Where we going hiking?
answer: Into the woods.

question: Is this is a new form of therapy?
answer: Yeah, Bob, it's death therapy. It's a guaranteed cure.

question: Death therapy. I like it. This is pretty imaginative, Dr. M. Will this be in your new book?
answer: If it is, I'll dedicate it to you, how's that?

question: Great. Ow. That hurts. Ow. What is this now, pain therapy?
answer: Exactly. Now yell and scream and suffer!

question: Ow! Ahh! Ow! That really hurts.
answer: Say hello to Freud for me.

question: Dr. M, this hurts!
answer: Love hurts. Music to die by, Bob! I guess it was suicide, Fay. He tried it once, remember. Just goes to show, you never can tell.

question: I'm worried about getting gangrene, Dr. M! I think I get the point! At least I think I get the point. Maybe I'm not supposed to sit here. Maybe I'm supposed to undo these outer knots... So that my inner knots..., these strong..., restricting..., inner knots... Will come undone too. Yes!
answer: Ahh!

question: Death therapy cured me!
answer: No!

question: Yes! I used to be so afraid of everything, it was like dying a thousand deaths a day. Now, that you showed me I have only one death to be afraid of, I'm not afraid of anything anymore!
answer: NOOOO!

question: Don't be so modest! Dr. M.? Dr. M., I'm really cured! Did somebody leave the gas on?
answer: Why won't you go away! I disgraced myself on national television! No one will buy my book! My family's going to hate me!

question: Dr. M., your family loves you.
answer: I'M FINISHED!

question: Dr. M. you have the crown jewels of England all around you. You have a wife with a generous heart. You have great kids and an incredible sister.
answer: Stay away from my sister!

question: Dr. M, you have a fam! You know, I'm beginning to think you're an ingrate.
answer: What?!

question: People are miserable all over the world and you're killing yourself? You should be ashamed.
answer: Don't talk that way to me!

question: Maybe I was wrong about you.
answer: Do you hear me?!

question: Maybe you're not so good after all.
answer: I'll kill you!

question: Phone. Phone. Bob's... unavailable right now. Can... I take a message? Tucson canceling order... Any message why?
answer: It's not a priority right now.

question: Not priority... right now. Why? Sure. Though, you know there is another way to look at it. Well... if you gave a new toothbrush and taught dental hygiene to every student at your school... In the long run you'd save them thousands of dollars. I mean look at the cost of dental bills. I bet I could have put my kids through college with what I've spent on fillings.
answer: That's an interesting point.

question: It is, isn't it? Maybe you should try the toothbrushes. You might do a lot for education by saving teeth.
answer: Huh. I never thought of that. I tell you what. Tell Bob we'll take the order and see how it goes.
